ygData.subject: Lost friendship?

(Sorry I took so long to reply. Netscape hasn't been very nice to me lately, 
but everything seems alright now^_^)

When Tavatron touched the energy coil a flood of thoughts and scattered 
memories filtered through her I-Comp. Most of them were lost, but a select 
few remained. Dinobot was upset about something, but what it was puzzled 
her. She was there, by his side, still�

Then it dawned on her. He knew she had left. Tavatron hung her head as she 
sighed. There was so much about him she did not know, so much she had yet to 
understand. She had failed him when it had been her turn to stand by his 
side, both as a friend and a fellow warrior. She had acted cowardly, and 
done the only thing she knew how to do whenever something like this had 
happened. She panicked. If there had been something, anything she could have 
done she would have.

The thought never occurred to her that the wolf �bot�s mere presence could 
have been enough. Last time she had kept running, this time she came back. 
Perhaps if he would just ask her WHY she had left� no, deep down she knew he 
didn�t want an explanation, and she really didn�t want to give one. He was 
concerned with what she had done, not with why she had done it.

There was no excuse that could possibly make amends for what she had done. 
Her actions, however, did not warrant an attack on her honor. She was tired; 
exhausted both mentally and physically. It took her several moments to just 
process what he had said. So, in his eyes she was no longer a warrior? This 
one phrase cut her more deeply than an energon blade ever could. Whether or 
not he had meant it to mean just that did not concern her. She had taken it 
to mean he thought even less than what she thought of herself right now.

She wanted to yell, but couldn�t think of anything to say that wouldn�t end 
up with them impaled on each other�s swords/claws. The room seemed to dim 
slightly as Tavatron raised her head. The look that met her tired gaze was 
all she needed to confirm what she already thought. She had lost his 
respect. Very well, if he no longer saw her as a warrior than why should he 
concern himself with her welfare any longer? Dinobot had no idea just how 
much damage that one phrase, tone, and look had just done. Perhaps this was 
what he wanted. Tavatron stood at attention, her arms plastered to her 
sides. Her eyes were level, gazing directly forward. Her voice never wavered 
as she spoke in a monotonous, steady pitch. A voice she used only when 
addressing those above her, or when she thought it best not to let her real 
emotions show:

"I apologize for my earlier behavior. I assure you it will not happen 
again."

He no longer had respect for her, so why should she address him as if they 
were friends? It was amazing how quickly he could change his attitude toward 
others, and expect the rest of the world to change with him. He acted as if 
he were the only one suffering; the only one who had ever lost something 
they truly cared about. Well, if he ever did care about her at least now he 
wouldn�t have to worry about losing this fem �bot anymore. She had tried her 
best. She had tried to be nice, compassionate, even at times more like him. 
All she ever got in return was the occasional glare of disapproval. At times 
he had opened himself up to her, but it was too little too late. She was 
tired. Tired of trying to change what obviously was set in its ways:

"Beast mode."

Part of her wanted to stay, to argue this out, but he had crossed the line.

*I thought I knew him better�*

Tavatron thought solemnly as she turned to look behind her. The icy glare 
that she gave him was enough to chill the warmest of fires. Then again, his 
spark was coated in ice, so why should he even care?

*I guess I was wrong.*

Tavatron trotted out of the CR room, her head held level with the rest of 
her body. Once she was sure she was out of his sight she broke into a jog 
then a wild run. She needed time to think. She needed to collect her 
thoughts, and figure out what had just happened. If he followed her�

No, he wouldn�t. That would mean he�d have to apologize for what had been 
said. He had made it clear she was at fault, so why should he apologize? 
Tavatron bolted through the CF�s entrance, her mind racing. She eventually 
stopped running, finding herself where she had been only hours ago. The 
stump of the tree she had cut down while practicing seemed to taunt her, 
just daring her to continue her solo battling. Tavatron continued forward at 
a steady pace until she came to a cliff overlooking a vast forest.

She was a good ways from the CF now, but that was partially due to the fact 
she had been running at top speed. Her spark was racing and her legs sore 
from the run. Tavatron ignored all of this as she sat on her haunches, 
raised her muzzle heavenward and howled. It was a long, mournful howl, one 
even she didn�t know the meaning of. It surprised her that such a sound 
could originate from her hollow throat. But it did, and in essence it was 
the epitome of everything she had been feeling. All her sorrow, anger and 
hurt was summed up in one, plaintive howl.

The sound carried on the wind until it eventually died out. There was no 
reply, nor had she expected any. Tavatron lay her head down upon crossed 
paws as she watched the trees below her blow gently in the wind. This was 
exactly the kind of solitude and self-pity that got her stranded on this 
rock. However, Dinobot wouldn�t know that now, would he? He was too involved 
with his own problems. Perhaps she had acted a little rash, but if she meant 
anything to him at all he would come after her. But Tavatron knew better. He 
wouldn�t come. Why should he? She had abandoned him, twice. Only this time 
she wasn�t afraid, just disappointed.
